title.narrative: World Bank Lebanon Financing Facility

description.narrative: The Lebanon Financing Facility (LFF) seeks to support the immediate socio-economic recovery of vulnerable people and businesses following the explosion in Beirut on April 4, 2020, and to build the foundation for sustainable reconstruction of the Port of Beirut and affected neighborhoods. The LFF will be fully aligned with the priorities of the Lebanon Reform, Recovery and Reconstruction Framework (3RF). Furthermore, the fund will be guided by principles of inclusion, transparency and accountability, and it will seek to accelerate the design and implementation of targeted reforms and strengthen institutional mechanisms and capacities for multi-stakeholder dialogue, monitoring and oversight.

title.narrative: A. Enhanced support for survivors of SGBV in Beirut

A1: Number of SGBV survivor beneficiaries of social services in existing shelters and safe places.
A2: Support towards the establishment of a shelter for boys under protection orders.
A3: Capacitated NGO social workers in Integrated Digital Case Management Systems.
B. Improved outcomes for beneficiaries who avail of mental health services

B1: Targeted Step-by-Step interventions for youth, persons who have lost livelihoods, people with disabilities and migrants, including training and resourcing for e-mental health helpers.
B2: Targeted SH+ interventions for women survivors of SGBV in shelters and health workers, including training and resourcing for facilitators. Number of targeted Interventions
B3: Percentage of beneficiaries reporting positive changes to their mental health due the intervention.

C. Urgent environment, health and safety risks caused by the explosion are addressed inside and outside the Port of Beirut

C1: Demolition waste in Beirut Port safely disposed or recycled
C2: Hazardous and special waste outside Beirut Port safely disposed
C3: Affected marine ecosystem and green cover in Beirut restored
D. Programmatic housing recovery initiated with a focus on housing repairs, rental subsidies for the vulnerable and stabilization of cultural assets on a pilot basis

D1: Number of housing units repaired/rehabilitated
D2: Number of households benefiting from sustainable rental subsidy solutions
D3: Beneficiary selection criteria and enrollment systems for rentals and housing reconstruction support established and mechanisms for sustainable support to households established
D4: Damaged heritage assets and existing culture fabric protected through emergency management support

E. Strengthen the capacity of affected municipalities for smooth implementation, enhanced coordination and better management of rehabilitation and reconstruction activities throughout the recovery phase

E1: One-stop shops for obtaining rehabilitation permits have been established at the affected municipalities
E2: Capacity of municipal staff built for damage assessments, managing the one-stop shop, mapping and database of rehabilitation activities, participatory planning, etc.
E3: Collaborative partnership mechanisms and process established with civil society for rehabilitating damaged municipal services
